review.title: Dynamics of Belief: Abduction, Horn Knowledge Base And Database Updates
review.abstract: The dynamics of belief and knowledge is one of the major components of any autonomous system that should be able to incorporate new pieces of information. In order to apply the rationality result of belief dynamics theory to various practical problems, it should be generalized in two respects: first it should allow a certain part of belief to be declared as immutable; and second, the belief state need not be deductively closed. Such a generalization of belief dynamics, referred to as base dynamics, is presented in this paper, along with the concept of a generalized revision algorithm for knowledge bases (Horn or Horn logic with stratified negation). We show that knowledge base dynamics has an interesting connection with kernel change via hitting set and abduction. In this paper, we show how techniques from disjunctive logic programming can be used for efficient (deductive) database updates. The key idea is to transform the given database together with the update request into a disjunctive (datalog) logic program and apply disjunctive techniques (such as minimal model reasoning) to solve the original update problem. The approach extends and integrates standard techniques for efficient query answering and integrity checking. The generation of a hitting set is carried out through a hyper tableaux calculus and magic set that is focused on the goal of minimality. The present paper provides a comparative study of view update algorithms in rational approach. For, understand the basic concepts with abduction, we provide an abductive framework for knowledge base dynamics. Finally, we demonstrate how belief base dynamics can provide an axiomatic characterization for insertion a view atom to the database. We give a quick overview of the main operators for belief change, in particular, belief update versus database update.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: We live in an ever-changing world, and consequently our beliefs need to be revised when there is new information. If we come across a new piece of information that contradicts our current beliefs, we rationalize our convictions. Xiv: 150 1,06 206v 2 [cs.L O] 27 Jan 20In the last three decades, the field of computer science has been much larger than the mere number of crunches and strives to imitate the rational thinking of humans. A separate branch of the study, artificial intelligence (AI), has evolved to represent and manipulate knowledge in a computer system. Much work has been done to study the statistics of knowledge, i.e. the representation and derivation of fixed knowledge leading to the development of logic systems, has been designed in recent years, conceived in recent years, has proven to be an important tool to get a grip on static knowledge.

sections.heading: 2 Motivation
sections.text: In the general case of the viewpoint problem in a rational way, we show that the revision problem for knowledge bases is difficult to solve. So we limit the revision problem to Horn formulas. The connection between faith and database changes is interesting, because the two communities have independently looked at two problems that are very similar, and our goal is to highlight this connection. In such a case, we want to bridge the gap between philosophical and database theory. Wrobel's (Wrobel 1995) definition of the first order revision theory was helpful in framing our algorithms. On the other hand, we deal with the viewpoint problem. Keller and Minker's (Keller 1985 and Minker 1996) work is one of the motivators for the viewpoint problem.

sections.heading: 8.2 View update algorithm
sections.text: The key idea of the algorithm presented in this paper is to transform the given database into a logic program together with the request for an update of the view, using known minimal techniques to solve the original problem of updating the view. Intuition behind the transformation is to obtain a logic program in such a way that each (minimal) model of this transformed program represents a way to update the given view atom. We present two variants of our algorithm: One, discussed in this section, uses a trivial transformation procedure, but must look for minimal models; and the other performs a costly transformation, but does not require the calculation of the minimum models.

8.4 Incomplete to Complete Information
sections.text: Many of the suggestions in the literature on incomplete databases have focused on expanding the relationship model by introducing zero values. In this section, we will show how updating views provides the addition of incomplete information. More detailed surveys of this range can be found in (Meyden 1998). The earliest extension of the relationship model to incomplete information was that Codd (Codd 1979) proposed that missing values should be represented in tables by placing a special zero-value symbol in any place for which the value is unknown. Table 5.3, shows an example of a database applying this convention. Codd proposed an extension of the relational algebra for tables containing such zeros, based on three estimated logics and a zero-substitution preplex. In our general semantic scheme, the intended semantics of a database consisting of Codd tables can be described.

sections.heading: 9 Belief Update Vs Database Update
sections.text: In this section we give an overview of how faith updating is related to database updating. This section is motivated by the work of Hansson (Hansson 1991) and Keller (Keller 1985).

sections.heading: 9.1 View update vs Database update
sections.text: The problem of view update exists already three decades after Chen & Liao 2010 and Minker 1996. We take the evidence from Keller 1985, because a view update request does not match a database status. Such a view update request must not be translated without loosening the restriction that excludes view side effects. Otherwise, the view update request will be rejected by the view update translator. If we are lucky, there is exactly one way to perform the database update that leads to the desired view update. As the view is many-to-one, the new view update state can correspond to many database states. Of these database states, we may choose one that is "as close as possible" to the original database state, i.e. we want to minimize the impact of the view update on the database.

sections.heading: 10 Abductive framework for Horn knowledge base dynamics
sections.text: As discussed in Section 5, we have introduced Horn Knowledge Base Dynamics to deal with two important points: First, to deal with states of faith that do not necessarily need to be closed; and second, the ability to declare certain parts of faith immutable; there is another, radically new approach to deal with this problem, and this section addresses this problem. Indeed, this approach is very close to Hansson's (Hansson 1992) dyadic representation of faith; in the similar Abduction Model of Boutilier & Beche 1995 and Pagnucco 1996, we consider the immutable part to be the definition of a new logical system; by a logical system, we mean that it defines its own consistent relationship and closure.

sections.heading: 10.3 Relationship with the coherence approach of AGM
sections.text: Given the Horn Knowledge Base KB = < P, Ab, IC, K > represents a KB • belief set that is closed under CnP. We have defined how KB can be expanded, revised or merged. Now, the question is: Does our basic approach (in relation to the classical first-order logic) in relation to KB agree with the coherence approach (in relation to our successor CnP) of the Annual General Meeting to KB •? There is a problem in answering this question (similar practical problem Baral & Zhang 2005) because our approach requires that IC must be immutable and only the current knowledge K may be changed. On the contrary, the AGM approach treats each sentence in KB • equally and can eject sentences from CnP (IC). One way to solve this problem is to assume that sentences are more firmly anchored in CnP (IC) than others.

sections.text: In fact, most people who are in favour of gender equality cannot agree on a particular position, but on a particular position on which they want to base themselves.

sections.heading: 12 Conclusion and remarks
sections.text: We argued for the generalization of faith dynamics theory in two respects: to treat a certain part of knowledge as immutable; and to abandon the demand for a generalized algorithm for revision based on abductive procedures; the intended generalization was achieved by introducing the concept of horn-knowledge-base dynamics and generalized revision for the same. Furthermore, we investigated the relationship between horn-knowledge-base dynamics and abduction leading to a generalized algorithm for revision; the successfully demonstrated way Horn-knowledge-base dynamics is a fundamental characterization for updating the letters to a stratifiable (definitive) deductive database; in bridging the gap between faith dynamics and viewpoint actualizations, we observe that an equilibrium between computational efficiency and rationality must be achieved.

metadata.abstractText: The dynamics of belief and knowledge is one of the major components of any autonomous system that should be able to incorporate new pieces of information. In order to apply the rationality result of belief dynamics theory to various practical problems, it should be generalized in two respects: first it should allow a certain part of belief to be declared as immutable; and second, the belief state need not be deductively closed. Such a generalization of belief dynamics, referred to as base dynamics, is presented in this paper, along with the concept of a generalized revision algorithm for knowledge bases (Horn or Horn logic with stratified negation). We show that knowledge base dynamics has an interesting connection with kernel change via hitting set and abduction. In this paper, we show how techniques from disjunctive logic programming can be used for efficient (deductive) database updates. The key idea is to transform the given database together with the update request into a disjunctive (datalog) logic program and apply disjunctive techniques (such as minimal model reasoning) to solve the original update problem. The approach extends and integrates standard techniques for efficient query answering and integrity checking. The generation of a hitting set is carried out through a hyper tableaux calculus and magic set that is focused on the goal of minimality. The present paper provides a comparative study of view update algorithms in rational approach. For, understand the basic concepts with abduction, we provide an abductive framework for knowledge base dynamics. Finally, we demonstrate how belief base dynamics can provide an axiomatic characterization for insertion a view atom to the database. We give a quick overview of the main operators for belief change, in particular, belief update versus database update. Keyword: AGM, Belief Revision, Belief Update, Horn Knowledge Base Dynamics, Kernel Change, Abduction, Hyber Tableaux, Magic Set, View update, Update Propagation.
